questions.explanation: SMART goals are: Specific (clear and detailed), Measurable (quantifiable progress), Achievable (realistic yet challenging), Relevant (aligned with larger objectives), Time-bound (has a deadline). Example: 'Save $10,000 for house down payment by December 31st' vs vague 'save money.'

questions.text: What is the difference between outcome goals and process goals?
options: Outcome is the end result; process is the daily actions/systems that achieve it
questions.explanation: Outcome goal: 'Lose 30 pounds.' Process goal: 'Exercise 4x weekly and eat 5 servings of vegetables daily.' Outcome goals define success; process goals define behavior. Millionaires focus on process - control the inputs (daily actions), and outcomes follow naturally.

questions.text: What is visualization and why do successful people use it?
options: Mental rehearsal of achieving goals using all senses - programs subconscious and increases performance
Looking at pictures of rich people
questions.explanation: Visualization is vividly imagining achieving your goals - seeing, feeling, hearing the experience. Athletes use this to improve performance. It programs your subconscious, increases motivation, and primes your brain to recognize opportunities. Spend 5-10 minutes daily visualizing your success in detail.

questions.text: What is the purpose of writing goals down?
options: Written goals are 42% more likely to be achieved - activates RAS and creates psychological commitment
questions.explanation: Writing goals activates the Reticular Activating System (RAS) - your brain's filter for important information. It signals importance and triggers your subconscious to seek opportunities. Studies show written goals are 42% more likely to be achieved than unwritten ones. Review them daily.
